comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I'll have a dry martini please ... or maybe it has not been invented yet?  The sun is well over the yard-arm where I am.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: It's a long way from the ferry to Holyhead! :-)

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Looks like it must be 1860-1865 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Great_Eastern The Sept 1861 voyage looks like a contender - "On the second day out [from Liverpool] the wind increased to gale force, causing the ship to roll heavily"

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Although, the captain of the ship from 1866-78, during its cable-laying years, was a Wicklow man en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Halpin It seems odd that the saloon and dining saloon would be so luxuriously appointed for that kind of work though.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] The absolute earliest this could be is 1865, as Lawrence didn't set up in business until then. But logistically speaking, it was probably at least a few years after that.

(Robert French, photographer on three-quarters of our Lawrence Collection didn't even start working for William Lawrence until 1880-ish....)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Of course! Now I'm going to contradict everything I've just said. :-) From 1885 "She acted as an advertising hoarding—sailing up and down the Mersey for Lewis's Department Store". The other photos in the collection show large text on the side of the ship, including the word "Ladies" in very large letters. This must be around the time the photo was taken. She was also re-fitted as a liner after her cable-laying career and "used as a showboat, a floating palace/concert hall and gymnasium" which would explain the opulent interior. During that time she made an exhibition trip to Dublin telephonecollecting.org/greateastern.html So, that places it sometime between 1885 and 1888 when she was broken up for scrap.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Would you like me to upload the "Ladies" photo? It's absolutely mad!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
Irish Times, Friday 20th August 1886:

THE PROJECTED VISIT OF THE GREAT EASTERN TO DUBLIN

Wednesday 8th September:

THE GREAT EASTERN IS COMING

15th October 1886:

ARRIVAL OF THE GREAT EASTERN IN DUBLIN

30th October:

GREAT EASTERN, NORTH WALL DUBLIN, NOW OPEN DAILY

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Well then, October-ish 1886 for Arklow shots? Crikey, we might acually get an actual range of a few days for this one - going to have a sit-down...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: On first examination I thought how dangerous all that furniture would be on a rough crossing and then I saw the guy ropes on the chandeliers.  At least you could count on not being knocked out by them swinging.  Compare the dining room (even if it the first class) with those on todays cruise ships and it is more than in a restaurant or a great house, very plush and opulent.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I assume the Arklow stop would have been either on the way into Dublin (so, early-mid October) or after the Dublin visit, so maybe early 1887.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: According to this www.atlantic-cable.com/Cableships/GreatEastern/ the Great Eastern was towed to Dublin in the Spring of 1887 and then towed to Greenock where it lay on the 20th October 1887, the date it was auctioned. That reference to Spring 1887 must be wrong given the newspaper articles cited above - perhaps that was the date it was towed to Greenock?

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Some more photos of the ship www.maritimequest.com/side_wheel/great_eastern_1858/great...
